message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Grand challenges in model-driven engineering: an analysis of the state of the research
Paper Abstract: Abstract In 2017 and 2018, two events were held—in Marburg, Germany, and San Vigilio di Marebbe, Italy, respectively—focusing on an analysis of the state of research, state of practice, and state of the art in model-driven engineering (MDE). The events brought together experts from industry, academia, and the open-source community to assess what has changed in research in MDE over the last 10 years, what challenges remain, and what new challenges have arisen. This article reports on the results of those meetings, and presents a set of grand challenges that emerged from discussions and synthesis. These challenges could lead to research initiatives for the community going forward.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Overview

Software engineering research involves computer scientists doing academic research about software engineering.(no content)Empirical software engineering (ESE) is a subfield of software engineering research that uses empirical research methods to study and evaluate SE techniques.

## Research Organizations

Several major organizations conduct software engineering research:

- The Software Engineering Institute (SEI) is a federally funded research and development center in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, sponsored by the United States Department of Defense and administrated by Carnegie Mellon University.

- Lero, the Science Foundation Ireland Research Centre for Software, is a world-leading research centre hosted at University of Limerick with around 250 active researchers across eight Irish universities and three Institutes of Technology.

## Research Areas

Software engineering research spans a wide range of application domains from driverless cars to artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, fintech, govtech, smart communities, agtech and healthtech. Other active research areas include software maintenance and evolution, machine learning systems engineering, cloud engineering, and dependable and trustworthy ML/AI.

## Community Development

In 2014 a Research Software Engineer Association was created in UK, and other countries like the Netherlands, Germany, and the USA followed creating similar communities.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Model-driven engineering"

Links: [{"title":"Model-driven engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-driven_engineering"},{"title":"Metamodeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamodeling"},{"title":"Model-driven architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-driven_architecture"},{"title":"Model-driven - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-driven"},{"title":"MERODE - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MERODE"},{"title":"Model-based testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_testing"},{"title":"Model-driven interoperability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_Driven_Interoperability"},{"title":"Data modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_modeling"},{"title":"Model-based systems engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_systems_engineering"},{"title":"Model transformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_transformation"}]

## Model-Driven Engineering

Model-driven engineering (MDE) is a software development methodology that focuses on creating and exploiting domain models, which are conceptual models of all the topics related to a specific problem.(no content)It highlights and aims at abstract representations of the knowledge and activities that govern a particular application domain, rather than the computing (i.e. algorithmic) concepts.

### Key Goals and Benefits

The MDE approach is meant to increase productivity by maximizing compatibility between systems (via reuse of standardized models), simplifying the process of design (via models of recurring design patterns in the application domain), and promoting communication between individuals and teams working on the system (via a standardization of the terminology and the best practices used in the application domain).

### Core Concept

In model-driven development, technical artifacts such as source code, documentation, tests, and more are generated algorithmically from a domain model.(no content)One important move in model-driven engineering is the systematic use of model transformation languages.

### Standards and Tools

The Object Management Group (OMG) initiative Model-Driven Architecture (MDA) is leveraged by several of their standards such as Meta-Object Facility, XMI, CWM, CORBA, Unified Modeling Language, and QVT. Additionally, the Eclipse "eco-system" of programming and modelling tools represented by the Eclipse Modeling Framework allows the creation of tools implementing the MDA standards of the OMG.

Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Grand challenges in model-driven engineering: an analysis of the state of the research". Here's a summary of what was done:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey

This paper is classified as a **survey** because it analyzes the state of research, practice, and art in model-driven engineering. It synthesizes findings from expert meetings and presents grand challenges that have emerged—it's fundamentally a literature analysis and position paper, not a proposal of new methods or techniques.

**Key Triples Identified:**

1. **Model-driven engineering** (concept)
   - Relation: uses
   - Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-driven_engineering
   - Relevance: The paper analyzes the state of research and challenges in model-driven engineering, which is the core subject of the survey.

   - Relation: uses
   - Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_software_engineering
   - Relevance: The paper examines the state of research in MDE, focusing on research methodologies and challenges in the field.
